image.altText: A streetscape with a young boy riding a push bike.

props.synopsis: Two remote schools are missing out on $3.4 million per year because of the NT government's choice of funding method, which the education minister confirmed would remain in place until 2025.

title.children: 'They don't care': FOI documents reveal level of underfunding in remote NT schools

image.altText: Scene of car crash with investigators under a tent near a crashed truck and car near bush on side of road

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police have confirmed six people died in a head-on crash involving a road train and four-wheel drive on the Stuart Highway.

title.children: Six people killed in Northern Territory's deadliest road crash in 16 years, police say

image.altText: People standing in individual booths at a polling centre.

props.synopsis: Early voting for the Voice to Parliament referendum kicks off this week for those who are unable to vote on October 14.

title.children: Early referendum voting starts today in half the country. Here's where to vote early and who's eligible

image.altText: An aerial photo of a small, busy town at sunset with a hotel in the foreground and cars parked along the main street.

props.synopsis: Converted airports, refurbished nursing homes, caravans, sheds and school camps aren't considered suitable housing options. But they're all in the mix as workers struggle to find a place to live near their workplace that they can afford.

title.children: This seaside town is so popular that employers are turning an aged care home into accommodation for their staff

image.altText: A woman stands with her mouth open while facing a man.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce see sparks fly as she attends Kansas City Chiefs game, five dead after church roof collapses in Mexico. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A bearded man in a white lab coat seated in front of a lab fridge. He holds up a glass jar of red seaweed floating in water

props.synopsis: Seaweed, cows and cutting-edge science: This is how Sam Elsom swapped fashion for farming to spearhead a revolutionary climate change solution. But he's facing a major obstacle.

title.children: How a humble seaweed inspired Sam to build an innovative solution to climate change

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australian stocks start the final quarter of this year lower, while the Reserve Bank is almost universally tipped to hold interest rates steady in tomorrow's board meeting. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX drops ahead of RBA interest rate decision, Wall Street mixed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares were flat after midday, while cautious investors awaited the key interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank on Tuesday. The RBA is scheduled to give out its interest rate decision, with expectations that it would hold its key interest rate steady at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday but hike it to a peak of 4.35 per cent next quarter, a Reuters poll of economists showed. Separately, data in the US on Friday showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August. The Federal Reserve tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target. Back home, financials descended 0.1 per cent with two of the "big four" banks trading in negative territory. A slump in oil prices took energy stocks lower 0.7 per cent. Sector major Woodside Energy and Santos toppled over 0.1 per cent. On the other hand, gold stocks and technology stocks gained 0.8 per cent and 0.2 per cent, respectively. Export reliant miners also rose 0.6 per cent, with behemoths BHP and Rio Tinto trading in the positive territory. Among individual stocks, Liontown Resources gained 0.7 per cent after Hancock prospecting increased its stake to 12.4 per cent in the company.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX flat after midday

children.content: Australian shares were flat after midday, while cautious investors awaited the key interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank on Tuesday.

The RBA is scheduled to give out its interest rate decision, with expectations that it would hold its key interest rate steady at 4.10 per cent on Tuesday but hike it to a peak of 4.35 per cent next quarter, a Reuters poll of economists showed.

Separately, data in the US on Friday showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August. The Federal Reserve tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target.
Back home, financials descended 0.1 per cent with two of the "big four" banks trading in negative territory.
A slump in oil prices took energy stocks lower 0.7 per cent.
Sector major Woodside Energy and Santos toppled over 0.1 per cent.
On the other hand, gold stocks and technology stocks gained 0.8 per cent and 0.2 per cent, respectively.
Export reliant miners also rose 0.6 per cent, with behemoths BHP and Rio Tinto trading in the positive territory.
Among individual stocks, Liontown Resources gained 0.7 per cent after Hancock prospecting increased its stake to 12.4 per cent in the company.
(Reuters)
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the United Kingdom and countries like Austria and Finland, about one in six people live in social housing, which provides dwellings to vital workers, people on low incomes and those in vulnerable situations like homelessness, family violence or disability. In Australia, that number is fewer than one in 20, with decades-long waiting lists and pressing demand. Converted airports, refurbished nursing homes, caravans, sheds and school camps aren't considered suitable housing options. But they're all in the mix as workers struggle to find a place to live near their workplace that they can afford. Read more from Daniel Ziffer .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Workers and low income earners suffer a housing shortage

featuredLink.title: This seaside town is so popular that employers are turning an aged care home into accommodation for their staff

children.content: In the United Kingdom and countries like Austria and Finland, about one in six people live in social housing, which provides dwellings to vital workers, people on low incomes and those in vulnerable situations like homelessness, family violence or disability.
In Australia, that number is fewer than one in 20, with decades-long waiting lists and pressing demand.
Converted airports, refurbished nursing homes, caravans, sheds and school camps aren't considered suitable housing options.
But they're all in
the mix as workers struggle to find a place to live near their workplace that they can afford.
Read more from
Daniel Ziffer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Billionaire Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting increased its stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources, the company said, moving it closer to being able to block a $US4.3 billion bid by US-based Albemarle for Liontown. Hancock said on Friday it raised its stake from 10.7 per cent last month to 12.4 per cent, paying no more than $3.00 per additional share. Hancock would be able to block the Albemarle deal with a 15 per cent position. Last month, Liontown accepted Albemarle's revised $US4.3 billion bid, or $3 a share. Albemarle, the world's largest lithium producer, is seeking to secure supplies of the key electric vehicle battery metal. The offer is part of a surge of interest in Australian lithium assets amid the clean energy transition. Hancock said last month it may seek a position on Liontown's board and could help the company bring its lithium resources to production. Last week, Liontown raised its capital cost to first production estimate for its Kathleen Valley lithium project by 6 per cent to $951 million but confirmed it would meet its target for production to start in mid-2024. Hancock said the increased cost estimate underscored the project's "significant execution, operational ramp-up and market risks." Hancock said that the actual capital cost for the project could be in excess of $1 billion, factoring in inflation over time. Ms Rinehart, Australia's richest person, owns shares in lithium companies such as Patriot Battery Metals and Delta Lithium, in line with her recent focus on the sector.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hancock inches towards blocking stake in Liontown

children.content: Billionaire Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting increased its stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources, the company said, moving it closer to being able to block a $US4.3 billion bid by US-based Albemarle for Liontown.

Hancock said on Friday it raised its stake from 10.7 per cent last month to 12.4 per cent, paying no more than $3.00 per additional share. Hancock would be able to block the Albemarle deal with a 15 per cent position.

Last month, Liontown accepted Albemarle's revised $US4.3 billion bid, or $3 a share. Albemarle, the world's largest lithium producer, is seeking to secure supplies of the key electric vehicle battery metal. The offer is part of a surge of interest in Australian lithium assets amid the clean energy transition.
Hancock said last month it may seek a position on Liontown's board and could help the company bring its lithium resources to production.

Last week, Liontown raised its capital cost to first production estimate for its Kathleen Valley lithium project by 6 per cent to $951 million but confirmed it would meet its target for production to start in mid-2024.

Hancock said the increased cost estimate underscored the project's "significant execution, operational ramp-up and market risks." Hancock said that the actual capital cost for the project could be in excess of $1 billion, factoring in inflation over time.
Ms Rinehart, Australia's richest person, owns shares in lithium companies such as Patriot Battery Metals and Delta Lithium, in line with her recent focus on the sector.

image.altText: A student at Yipirinya School wiping his eye.

props.synopsis: For decades, an eye disease known as trachoma was stealing the sight of Indigenous Australians. Now, the disease is on its way to being eradicated.

title.children: How this little-known eye infection is still stealing sight in parts of Australia

image.altText: A Brisbane Broncos NRL player scores a try in the grand final.

props.synopsis: Penrith launches a comeback for the ages to earn legendary status, Brisbane is made to pay for botched drop-outs, while Ezra Mam lights up the grand final. These are the five quick hits from Penrith's third consecutive premiership triumph.

title.children: NRL grand final five quick hits: Costly kicking errors crush Broncos despite Mam magic

image.altText: a house for sale in the brisbane suburb of stafford with the sale sign in the front yard

props.synopsis: Housing data for September shows prices rose 0.8 per cent, led by Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth, despite a gradual increase in properties for sale and higher interest rates.

title.children: House prices on track to hit new record high, continuing to frustrate first home buyers

image.altText: Georgia Godwin performs on the beam

props.synopsis: Australian gymnast Georgia Godwin is peaking at 25, an age that historically would've seen her long retired from the sport. She is just one of many gymnasts extending their careers.

title.children: Most gymnasts traditionally retire in their early 20s, but Australian Georgia Godwin is just getting going

image.altText: Koala wrapped in yellow blanket being held by staff member as another staff member moves to treat it. Onlookers watching on.

props.synopsis: The Port Macquarie Koala Hospital, which began in the garage of its founders and went on to become a leading force in national research and conservation efforts, is celebrating 50 years.

title.children: Koala hospital that drew global attention during Black Summer bushfires marks 50 years

image.altText: Fraser McReight dives over

props.synopsis: The Wallabies conceded the first try and had two players sent to the sin bin, but still managed to keep their faint Rugby World Cup hopes alive with a victory over Portugal — now they need Os Lobos to do them a huge favour.

title.children: Five quick hits — a shock Portugal lead and the Wallabies hold firm with 13 men to stay alive at the World Cup

image.altText: Red clouds from a bushfire above farmland in East Gippsland.

props.synopsis: Crews are working to contain multiple fires in Victoria's east as forecast winds approach, with confirmation at least one house and about 5,000 hectares have burnt in the spring blazes.

title.children: Home lost as Victorian authorities warn weekend bushfires 'a taste of what is to come'

image.altText: A full-body pic of an echidna's side highlights its short hair and 5cm-long spikes. Its short beak digs into vibrant grass

props.synopsis: Some of the most elusive sounds in nature — echidnas talking to each other — have finally been recorded. Could this be how the spiky creatures flirt during breeding season?

title.children: With a grunt, a coo and a wheeze, echidnas recorded communicating for the first time

image.altText: Jesse Arthars of the Brisbane Broncos sits against a goalpost after the NRL grand final.

props.synopsis: Coming so close to winning the NRL premiership and missing out has proven hard to overcome for some sides, and the most brutal but effective teacher for others. Now we will see how the Broncos handle it, writes Jon Healy.

title.children: The Broncos are young, but one key piece is on a different timeline and the clock is ticking after the grand final

image.altText: A sign on the roadside displaying coloured triangles with different fire risk ratings, with dense, green bushland behind it.

props.synopsis: For some people, the coming warmer months are not a celebration. They are something to fear, or feel sad about, writes Tara Crandon.

title.children: Not everyone is excited about the warmer months. For some, summer can trigger anxiety and grief

image.altText: A firefighter in front of a room on fire.

props.synopsis: The fire broke out in the early hours of Sunday in adjoining nightclubs in Atalayas, on the outskirts of the city Murcia in south-east Spain.

title.children: At least 13 dead in Spanish nightclub fire as families search for missing people

image.altText: Rory McIlroy throws his hat and grimaces

props.synopsis: Rory McIlroy said he was "the angriest I have ever been in my career" after his altercation on day two of the Ryder Cup. But he was able to refocus and led Europe to a dominant victory in Rome.

title.children: 'Angriest' Rory McIlroy leads Europe to dominant Ryder Cup victory over USA

image.altText: Nathan Cleary

props.synopsis: Brisbane had Penrith dead to rights with 20 minutes left in the grand final but they gave Nathan Cleary just enough time to cement his legend.

title.children: Nathan Cleary's NRL grand final performance cements his place alongside modern greats

image.altText: A woman with a pink shawl over her shoulders holds a newborn baby in her arms

props.synopsis: With no local maternity services, women in Bourke cannot have their babies on country, but they are being welcomed back to their ancestral land.

title.children: Baby Amahlee wasn't born on country, but an ancient Indigenous tradition has welcomed her home

image.altText: A video screen grab of an explosion on the side of a street.

props.synopsis: The Turkish defence ministry says its warplanes have carried out raids on suspected Kurdish rebel targets in northern Iraq following a suicide attack on a government building in the Turkish capital.

title.children: Türkiye strikes suspected Kurdish militant targets in northern Iraq after suicide attack in Ankara

image.altText: Rebecca Jeffcoat wearing goggles and sub-zero protective clothing in Antarctic landscape.

props.synopsis: It's one of the most challenging work environments on the planet. But with hundreds of applicants, the process of selecting the best candidate takes eight months and resembles a reality TV contest.

title.children: Reckon you can handle a year in Antarctica as a station leader? This is what it takes to pass the test

image.altText: An official is taken away on a stretcher

props.synopsis: A horrific hammer mishap has resulted in an official at the Asian Games being hospitalised after an errant throw saw the projectile smash into and break the 62-year-old's leg.

title.children: Horror hammer mishap sees official hospitalised at Asian Games

image.altText: A black and white image of men and women standing in front of a tall wooden church

props.synopsis: A fundraising effort to help save an 80-year-old church that embraced Aboriginal spirituality off a far-flung island of northern Australia is underway, with those involved saying it would preserve much more than just a building.

title.children: At 92, Sister Anne Gardiner is in a race against time to save this historical church on the Tiwi Islands

image.altText: Queensland police badge says "with honour we serve"

props.synopsis: Police will allege the 74-year-old victim was thrown from the first-floor balcony of a unit in Yeronga, striking the cement below and sustaining serious head injuries.

title.children: Man charged with murder after elderly man allegedly thrown from balcony in Brisbane suburb

image.altText: Elise Archer rests her head on her hand in parliament.

props.synopsis: Former Tasmanian Liberal MP Elise Archer says she's "reconsidering" quitting state parliament and might sit as an Independent, which an electoral analyst says could trigger an early state election.

title.children: Elise Archer 'reconsidering' quitting parliament, early election risk for Tasmanian Liberals
